title: The Temple Completed
shortSummary: Ezra 6 recounts the completion of the temple in Jerusalem under the decree of King Darius, fulfilling God's promise through the Persian kings. The chapter highlights the restoration of proper worship, the dedication of the temple, and the celebration of Passover, emphasizing God's faithfulness and the importance of obedience to His commands.
timeline: c. 516 BC - Completion of the Second Temple during the reign of Darius I

keyCharacters.name: Darius the King
keyCharacters.description: Persian king who confirmed Cyrus's decree and ordered the completion of the temple in Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: Tatnai
keyCharacters.description: Governor beyond the river who was instructed to allow the Jews to build the temple without interference.

keyCharacters.name: Haggai
keyCharacters.description: Prophet who encouraged the Jews to rebuild the temple, playing a key role in their spiritual motivation.

keyCharacters.name: Zechariah
keyCharacters.description: Prophet and son of Iddo, who alongside Haggai, prophesied to inspire the rebuilding of the temple.

definitions.definition: Ancient documents or records written on scrolls, used here to refer to official decrees stored in the royal archives.
An ancient unit of measurement roughly equal to 18 inches, used to describe the temple's dimensions.
A sacrificial offering completely consumed by fire on the altar, symbolizing atonement and dedication to God.
A Jewish feast commemorating Israel's deliverance from Egypt, celebrated with the sacrifice of a lamb and unleavened bread.

outline.heading: Darius's Decree to Rebuild the Temple
outline.description: King Darius orders a search of the royal archives and finds Cyrus's original decree to rebuild the temple. He commands local officials to support the Jews and provides resources, warning against interference with severe penalties. This section demonstrates God's providential preservation of His plan through secular authorities.

outline.heading: Completion of the Temple
outline.description: The Jewish elders, encouraged by prophets Haggai and Zechariah, complete the temple according to God's command and the Persian kings' decrees. The completion marks a significant moment of restoration and obedience to God's covenant.

outline.heading: Dedication of the Temple
outline.description: The people celebrate the temple's dedication with joy, offering numerous sacrifices and organizing the priests and Levites for worship. This section highlights the restoration of proper worship and reverence for God.

outline.heading: Celebration of Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread
outline.description: The returning exiles observe Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread with purity and joy, signifying their renewed commitment to God and His covenant. God's blessing is evident in their joy and the king's favorable attitude toward their work.

application: Trust in God's sovereign providence even when circumstances seem uncertain, knowing He can use earthly rulers to fulfill His purposes.
Obey God's commands faithfully, as the Israelites did in rebuilding the temple and restoring worship.
Celebrate and honor God with joy and reverence, recognizing His faithfulness in our lives.
Commit to spiritual purity and communal worship, following the example of the Israelites in observing Passover.

keyVerses.text: And the elders of the Jews builded, and they prospered through the prophesying of Haggai the prophet and Zechariah the son of Iddo. And they builded, and finished it, according to the commandment of the God of Israel, and according to the commandment of Cyrus, and Darius, and Artaxerxes king of Persia.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the fulfillment of God's promise through prophetic encouragement and royal decrees, emphasizing obedience and divine blessing.

keyVerses.text: And the children of Israel, the priests, and the Levites, and the rest of the children of the captivity, kept the dedication of this house of God with joy,
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the joyful response of God's people upon the completion and dedication of His house.

keyVerses.text: And the children of Israel, which were come again out of captivity, and all such as had separated themselves unto them from the filthiness of the heathen of the land, to seek the LORD God of Israel, did eat,
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the importance of holiness and separation from sin in seeking God.
